title: Know the foe: Boise State flexing defensive muscle
text:
Know the foe: Boise State flexing defensive muscle Kelly Lyell , kellylyell@coloradoan.com 3:46 p.m. MDT October 9, 2015 Boise State linebacker Tanner Vallejo (20) celebrates with the defensive player of the game trophy following the Fiesta Bowl. (Photo: Mark J. Rebilas/USA TODAY Sports) 2 CONNECT 5 TWEET 1 LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Boise State’s high-scoring offense gets all the attention, but the defense is the strength of this year’s team. 
The 25th-ranked Broncos have the No. 2 rushing defense in the nation, limiting opponents to an average of 51.8 yards a game, and they lead the nation in interceptions with 11. They’re No. 7 in total defense, giving up just 260.2 yards a game and No. 8 in scoring defense, allowing only 12.4 points a game. 
“Those guys are playing well; they’re flying around,” second-year coach Bryan Harsin said earlier this week as the Broncos (4-1, 1-0 Mountain West) prepared for Saturday’s game at CSU (2-3, 0-1 MW). “It starts up front, but I like the mentality that we have on that side of the ball.” 
It starts up front, Harsin said, with a seven-man rotation at the three defensive line positions that includes five seniors and two juniors. Behind them is a talented group of linebackers, led by the most valuable player of last year’s Fiesta Bowl win over Arizona, Tanner Vallejo. 
CSU VS. BOISE STATE : 
Game Day Guide: Boise State vs. CSU football 
The secondary is even better, with safety Darian Thompson and cornerback Donte Deayon, both seniors, tied for the lead in career interceptions among active players with 17 apiece – one shy former Utah safety Eric Weddle’s MW record. 
Strong defensive play has been a big part of Boise State’s rise to national prominence over the past 15 years, Harsin said. But this year’s unit might be the best yet. 
“When I was the offensive coordinator here (2006-12), no one appreciated them more than I did, because I know how we won games,” Harsin said. “I know the turnovers, I know the field position. I knew all those things that we took advantage of as an offensive team, and it was all because of our defense.” 
•The Broncos have gone 1112-11 in league play over the past 16 years, winning two titles in the Big West (1999, 2000), eight in the Western Athletic (2002-06, 2008-10) and two in the Mountain West (2012 and 2014) conferences. 
•Boise State quarterback Brett Rypien, a true freshman, set a Washington state record for career passing yards with 13,044 at Shadle Park High School in Spokane. He broke his uncle Mark Rypien’s Greater Spokane League record of 4,965 passing yards by the end of his junior year. Mark Rypien was the MVP of Super Bowl XXVI with the Washington Redskins.
